title: 104_hr2499
content: The "Ethics in Foreign Lobbying Act of 1995" prohibits contributions and expenditures by multicandidate political committees sponsored by foreign-controlled corporations and associations. The "Ethics in Foreign Lobbying Act of 1995" prohibits multicandidate political committees or separate segregated funds from foreign-controlled corporations or certain organizations with foreign funding from making contributions or expenditures for Federal elections. The Federal Election Commission is tasked with enforcing these restrictions. The "Ethics in Foreign Lobbying Act of 1995" requires disclosure of ownership interests and operating fund sources in political committees or funds associated with foreign-controlled entities. The "Ethics in Foreign Lobbying Act of 1995" mandates disclosure of ownership interests and funding sources in political committees linked to foreign-controlled entities. The Commission must maintain a list of these committees and funds, including reported amounts and percentages. Definitions for terms like "foreign-owned corporation," "multicandidate political committee," and "separate segregated fund" are provided in the Act. The Act defines terms like "separate segregated fund" and "foreign national" in relation to political committees and funding sources. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 prohibits foreign nationals from influencing election-related activities of entities like corporations or political committees. Additionally, a clearinghouse of political activities information will be established within the Federal Election Commission. A clearinghouse of public information on the political activities of foreign principals and agents will be established within the Federal Election Commission. This information will include publicly disclosed registrations and reports required by the Federal Regulation of Lobbying Act and the Foreign Agents Registration Act, as well as details from public hearings as printed in the Congressional Record. The Federal Election Commission will establish a clearinghouse for public information on political activities of foreign principals and agents. The clearinghouse will disclose information on honoraria, gifts, travel, income, post-congressional employment, and conflict of interest regulations. The Director, appointed by the Commission, will manage the clearinghouse for a single term of up to 5 years. Funding will be authorized as needed for its operations. Authorized funding for the clearinghouse activities as necessary. SEC. 5. Duties and responsibilities of the director of the clearinghouse. The Director is responsible for developing a system for filing, coding, and indexing reports under the Act. They must make copies of registrations and reports available for public inspection and copying, and can provide copies upon request for a fee. No information from these documents can be sold. The Director is responsible for compiling and summarizing information from registrations and reports required by the Act. This includes political activities related to issues before Congress and the executive branch, as well as activities of individuals, organizations, foreign principals, and foreign agents with common interests. The Director is responsible for compiling and summarizing information from registrations and reports required by the Act, including political activities related to issues before Congress and the executive branch. The information compiled is made available to the public within 30 days after each quarterly period and published in the Federal Register. Additionally, rules, regulations, and forms are prescribed within 150 days of the Act's enactment to carry out its provisions effectively. Special studies or reports on political activities can be prepared and submitted to Members of Congress upon request. The Act requires accurate transfer of political information to a clearinghouse and investigation by the Comptroller General for any discrepancies. Definitions include issues before Congress as all matters related to pending bills or resolutions. The term "issue before the executive branch" refers to all matters related to actions or possible actions by any executive agency or officer. The term "issue before the executive branch" refers to matters related to actions by any executive agency or officer, excluding appointments in the competitive service or issues before Congress. AMENDMENTS TO THE FOREIGN AGENTS REGISTRATION ACT OF 1938, AS AMENDED. Amendments to the Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938 include changes to reporting requirements and exemptions. The amendments specify new filing deadlines and forms for reporting, as well as a requirement for persons seeking exemption to file a request with the Attorney General. The Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938 has been amended to include civil penalties for violations such as failure to file registration statements, omitting material facts, or making false statements. The penalties range from $2,000 to $5,000 per violation, with consideration given to the nature and duration of the violation. Administrative law judges can compel witnesses and evidence with subpoenas during investigations and hearings. Failure to comply can result in a court order and contempt charges.
